title: London to become a place 'we work but don't live'
text:

Wed, Oct 14, 2015, 02:51 BST - UK Markets open in 5 hrs 9 mins London to become a place 'we work but don't live' By Anna White | Telegraph – Sun, Oct 11, 2015 22:21 BST 0.0000 
The exodus of homebuyers from London hits epic new levels 
Families and young workers who are in rental accommodation in London, but looking to buy their first home, are leaving the capital in their droves to get on to the property ladder, forced out by high house prices. 
More than two thirds of tenants buying their first home are escaping London so they can afford a place of their own. 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) research from the UK's largest estate and lettings agent, Countrywide (Other OTC: CTYWY - news ) , has revealed that 63pc of tenants who are taking their first step on the property ladder are moving outside London where they are finding that homes on average are £93,000 cheaper. 
The gap (NYSE: GPS - news ) between the places where people can afford to rent and where they can afford to buy has widened in every year since the market downturn in 2008, according to the study. 
Johnny Morris, director of research at Countrywide, said: “Renting enables many tenants to live in areas where they could not afford to buy but that means aspiring home owners often have to look elsewhere to find a home they can afford. It’s common for first time buyers to make sacrifices to buy their first home, so with price rises in recent years outstripping income growth, more are choosing to bypass rising prices by looking further for cheaper areas." 
Tenants in the south of England tend to move furthest to get onto the housing ladder. This is where the chasm between where people can afford to rent and buy is largest and has widened the most since 2012. 
In London and the South East house prices have increased 42pc since 2012, while rents have only climbed by 19pc. 
This is a long-standing London trend as young families seek to establish the family home in locations that can offer all of the amenities they expect; a garden, good schools and a community feel that isn't always easy in inner London," says Adam Challis," head of residential reseacr at JLL. "The trend relies on the next generation of young professionals to continue to be able to afford to rent in these inner London locations. Increasingly, they are competing for the same locations and even properties as affordability pressures place limits on where young professionals can live." 
And fears continue to grow from economic bodies and property agents that many young families and professionals will no longer be able to live and work in London . 
Russell Quirk, founder of online agent eMoov, said: "This does not bode well for London as whilst it is woefully short of supply of property, an upward tweak to interest rates, another cross rail type travel link (Crossrail 2 for instance) could also dampen demand further. Will we even eventually see London as a place that people work but they don’t live ." 
Across the country, renters who bought a home in the last year, did so in locations where the average house price was £35,000 lower than where they were renting. 
Further north, however, tenants tend to be less constrained by affordability due to cheaper house prices. Tenants buying in the North East, North West and Yorkshire, tend to buy in similarly priced areas to where they are renting.
